newsitem.title: UK: SHELL BACKERS SEE EVIDENCE OF COMING GROWTH.
newsitem.headline: SHELL BACKERS SEE EVIDENCE OF COMING GROWTH.

text.p: Shell's second-quarter results gave little reason to be cheerful, but investors should not ignore clear signs pointing to brighter times ahead, several leading analysts said.
"They have given sufficient excuses for the disappointing results and our view is that the long-term growth story is intact," said Paul Spedding at Kleinwort Benson.
The pound's strength and one-off setbacks in the chemicals sector are holding back Shell now, but the oil giant's upstream activities should fuel profits in years to come, Shell's supporters said.
Paradoxically, it is a sharp 16 percent fall in Shell's capital expenditure which indicates the Anglo-Dutch group is on course, said Fergus Macleod at NatWest Markets.
Rather than fearing a weaker asset base, he saw the drop as evidence Shell's managers are spending their money more wisely.
He pointed to British Petroleum's recovery in the early 1990s which was also preceded by a sudden capital expenditure slowdown.
The same happened with Shell's U.S. unit Shell Oil, which in recent years has taken the lead in the group's drive to cut out fat.
"Clearly the drive to improve returns in downstream and chemicals is not yet evident," Macleod said.
"But the fact Shell is undershooting its capital budget is clear evidence pressure is mounting on the operational management for better results," he added.
This argument, however, failed to convince every analyst in the industry. Several said Shell clearly underperforms its peer group in terms of return on capital employed.
They also believed investors will have to wait too long before Shell's sharper focus will start bearing fruit.
"It's always jam tomorrow with Shell," said SocGen's Irene Himona, who has downgraded the share to a "sell" from a "hold".
